Nazi Policies Toward Jews and Minorities

abstract.p: Richard F Starr letter responds to July 26 article on fate of Raoul Wallenberg; suggests Wallenberg was executed by Russians without sentencing

block.p: A July 26 news article reports that Russia ''has stopped taking the position that Raoul Wallenberg, the Swedish diplomat who saved many European Jews during the Holocaust, died a natural death while in Soviet hands.''

There is a 1947 source concerning the death of Wallenberg. According to the book ''Spies Without Cloaks,'' by Amy Knight, Gen. Anatoly Krayushkin, chief of the Lubyanka Archives, could not discount execution without sentencing, saying, ''Otherwise they would not have scratched his name out of the prison records; there would have been a medical certificate, an autopsy report and a record of cremation.''

A July 26 news article reports that Russia ''has stopped taking the position that Raoul Wallenberg, the Swedish diplomat who saved many European Jews during the Holocaust, died a natural death while in Soviet hands.''

There is a 1947 source concerning the death of Wallenberg. According to the book ''Spies Without Cloaks,'' by Amy Knight, Gen. Anatoly Krayushkin, chief of the Lubyanka Archives, could not discount execution without sentencing, saying, ''Otherwise they would not have scratched his name out of the prison records; there would have been a medical certificate, an autopsy report and a record of cremation.''

The book also says Izvestia in June 1993 cited a 1947 memorandum from Andrei Y. Vyshinsky, the deputy foreign minister, to his superior, Vyacheslav M. Molotov, the foreign minister, on the proposed ''liquidation'' of Wallenberg.
RICHARD F. STAAR Stanford, Calif., July 26, 2000
The writer is a senior fellow at the Hoover Institution.
